intro: Blepharis abyssinica, commonly known as the Abyssinian wireweed, is a flowering plant native to arid and semi-arid regions of Africa. It belongs to the Acanthaceae family and is characterized by its slender, wiry stems and small, tubular flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and is adapted to survive in drought conditions. Its flowering period usually occurs during the rainy season, and it produces small, capsule-like fruits that contain seeds. Due to its resilience, it is sometimes used in traditional medicine and as a source of forage for livestock.
